author: Take_Notice_Walk
body:
I own TSM, Nvidia, LAM research, ABVO

For me TSM. Pretty steady and decent value

NVDA. Overvalued but basically betting on the future being AI and blockchain 

LAM research for semis materials. Still room for growth. Pretty volatile so there might be more buying opportunities. 

Broadcom. A good dividend semi conductor. but i might consider dropping them for Qualcomm  

I dropped Skyworks because I felt they relied mostly on Apple. Probably a dumb move since I need semi geared toward 5G

author: stockpikr
body: Well since my portfolio is beating BLK, I'll stick with what I'm doing. FWIW, my portfolio from largest holding to smallest: MSFT, WING, TWLO, UNH, CRM, TTWO, HON, CSCO, V, AEP, AMZN, SWKS, BX, HD, REGN, NVDA, EEM, AAPL, VZ, JPM, NFLX and cash is over 10% at present.

author: CharlieBrown364
body:
I think QCOM has more potential than INTC, but is also riskier.

I do think that TSM, AVGO, and NVDA are better than all the other semiconductor stocks. I would definitely buy these over QCOM or INTC. 

If you want more growth (and therefore risk), you can go with AMD, MU, QRVO, or SWKS. Though do keep in mind that NVDA is growing very quickly. 

Also, AVGO has a nice dividend.

My top semiconductor stock is NVDA. I want to buy in, but it’s pretty overvalued. But it also keeps going up.

Like literally anything else, do some research, use your imagination

SWKS, AAPL, SNAP (but post-earnings it may be manipulated), INO

Since you won't do any research I'm not going to give you lower-profile plays

Start looking at BarChart.com unusual options and google the tickers you don't recognize

author: MaxandmillionB89
body: Are you personally invested in any semiconductors? I think it’s typically for this industry to be highly leveraged as you constantly trying to finance tour growth otherwise your competitors will destroy you. Although, I think Skyworks has no debt and should benefit nicely with new 5G iPhones. What about AMT and CCI? These 2 companies should benefit tremendously with building more and more towers to prepare for 5G coverage.

author: madinker
body:
Im,also in the same boat and been reading longer..
After so much i decided to create a portofoilio,this is all in,planing yet.. This is what i decided.
Divide in,long term and hi risk ..
Also found it easier sticking to what i know i love, computer n tech,cars and renewables..so i decided top down aproach look at industry and then go down..knowing about those theme made it easy 

Tech:
- amd when it between 60 and 70 soon, they have no comp,in the server or pc market till arm cpu is a think 3 years at least.
- Skyworks(swks) evey apple 5g need there chips
- tmsc they will thrive will the fall of intel and they produce amd cpu, an more probally intel too..

Ev 
Eveyone putting nio as tesla of china, but there only power is ip an tech, they dont produce there cars..

Byd they hated by stock msrket at 19usd they are what i will have the most .. Its a steal.. People forget that an ev car is battery is like the motor in terms of tech, and byd started im,90 in,nokia phones. They hugeeee..google themm

Now this is where i didnt think but after reading alot ..

Nickel and copper, there i big problem brewing w nickel in terms of supply.. With ev and batteries in the solar also booming.m nickel is 80% a battery .. An copper is basically main componen. Any Eletric motor,windturbine,ev motor is copper  with magnets..

Lithuims aslo as 1 tesla giga factory uses 25k ton lithuim the world produces 300k , a tetrafactory need 800k ..

Cathie wood investment style i like for New tech,warren buffet for long term..

This is sketch might change but the most i trust is copper nickel and byd.. That what i thinking the most ..they all linked in alot,of ways for the future..

Silver also not bad.. This might start in,phases but thats thr goal..

author: MrDopple68
body:
First post. Be kind (smiley face thingy).

Over the last 4 months I've built up a portfolio for the next 10+ years. With the Buffett strategy of hold, hold hold, but with mainly growth stocks, not value. I've divided into Big (over 5% of my portfolio), Medium (2 -4%) and Small (1.5% or less).

I'd be grateful if you all can point out the bad choices.

Big: Amazon, Tesla, Disney, Square, Illumina, Roku, Nvidia.

Med: FB, Alphabet, Netflix, Chegg, LuLu, Shopify, Spotify, MercadoLibre, Crowdstrike, The Trade Desk, Tractor Supplies, Walmart, Clorox, Pinterest, Huya, Sea, PayPal, Visa, Twilio, Adobe, Fastly, Docusign, Teladoc, Salesforce, Qualcoom, Skyworks, Waste Man, Starbucks, Invitae, Nike.

Small: 2U, Veeva, Activision, Autodesk, Etsy, Nokia, Pinduoduo, Zoom, TSM, Peloton, Okta, Zscaler, CrispR T, Xlinx, Splunk, Snap, Stratsys, Adyen, Teradyne, Lending Tree, Zillow, Nio.

As I say, I'm investing for the long term. I'm not selling any for short term gain, or trading. Cheers.

body: Currently I don’t own any shares in Intel (have positions in Nvidia, Skyworks and Lam Research). If the stock drops below $50, is this a good entry point? Do you guys think it has the potential to grow in the next 5 years?

author: iWriteYourMusic
body: SWKS tumbled actually

author: MustWarn0thers
body: Skyworks is fileting me right now. Lost like 50 percent of my position in a day.
Anyone else think SWKS earnings tomorrow could be a major bellwether, since it is a big supplier for AAPL, which is obviously a major bellwether for consumer spending and SPY?

author: Track_man
body: SWKS going to 200 soon get in while you can brothers

author: atol_ikan
body: Anyone have thoughts on Skyworks ???

author: peter-doubt
body:
Look to suppliers, not so much retail devices. 

SWKS... Up 40% since December.  (have it)

ETF: see if SMH suits you .. I'd like more nominations here, too.

author: ChartsNDarts
body:
They don’t even manage people’s money. They are a sell side research shop. Money managers pay Fundstrat for their research and opinions. Retail investors have nothing to do with it.

Tom Lee has been publishing a daily ‘Flash Report’ that includes a ton of interesting tidbits, Research, and news.

Fundstrat nailed the market bottom in March and called there would be no retest.

They are typically more bullish than average, but you just have to be cognizant if that. It doesn’t make their research useless.

author: APIglue
body:
Nobody wants to pay for information.  The few that do expect perfection: “4 out of 5 of your reports panned out, but we at GenericHardThing hold ourselves to a higher standard.”

It’s a symptom of churn culture of employment: you hire the “best” person who has somehow not shat the bed since high school and fire then for their inevitable first screwup. Then hire the “best” again. Rinse, repeat.  

One would think that financial firms who are largely cognizant of survivorship bias wouldn’t use it as a core HR and outsourcing practice, but they do.

author: KennanFan
body:
First, I never said it would be fine.  I literally said "it's terrifying."  Please be sure to read carefully, as comprehension requires that you carefully engage with the text.

Second, Trump is in fact a fascist and is completely transforming how the American government operates.  This is no secret unless you're willfully ignorant.

It's important to be cognizant of this if  you're investing in this industry.

author: hightyde992
body:
This is very very risky at the moment, especially the 8/21s, but could pay out huge. BOA (and other big banks in general) gave out A LOT of money in PPP loans, which are almost all currently under review for government forgiveness eligibility under the CARES Act. Depending on how that all plays out, they are going to come into a shitload of cash from the Feds to immediately extinguish those notes or have a shitload of PPP receivables on the books for the foreseeable future. Which given the true economic state of America, not just the imaginary stock market, could obviously result in catastrophic loan default losses from broke ass bankrupt corporations. 

Buffett obviously knows more than us plebs, and if I had to guess he’s banking on the better scenario here. I don’t generally obsessively sniff his nuts like a lot of boomer stock investors, but I do respect his success and am very cognizant of the fact that he wins more than he loses. I think he’ll win, I’m just unsure of whether it’s a short play or a long (>2yrs) play on his end.

author: The_GOATest1
body: Don’t worry most super large entities do this. They contract out the dev work to a Deloitte or Cognizant or Accenture who then send it over to their 100k+ person offshore centers to get the dogshit flowing and some poor sap stateside has to manage the stupid train
